												Short Version:Pros+ Great puzzles+ Good level design+ Most bosses are great+ All levels have challenges which enhance the replay value+ A good amount of collectibles+ Enjoyable singleplayer+ Amazing local co-opCons- Paper-thin story- Cheesy, dumb villain who is also a coward - he runs away from you from start to finish- Buggy online co-op- Voice acting is weak-Cutscenes are lackluster - The characters lips do not move; the camera angles "cleverly" change to make that unnoticeable."Long" version:I'm a big Tomb Raider fan and when Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light was announced, I thought it was a horrible idea. Fortunately, this game is quite an enjoyable experience.Lara finds herself in Central America looking for an artifact called the Mirror of Smoke. After a long journey, she is successful, but a group of mercenaries led by a local warlord ambushes Lara and misuses the mirror, unleashing Xolotl, the aztec god of death and darkness. Totec, the Guardian of Light, is then awaken - he informs Lara that Xolotl must be stopped until dawn, otherwise, the world will face certain doom.The story is really predictable and shallow. You release an evil god and you spend the whole game chasing him. The thing is, you are always on his heels, so he feels like a total coward, constantly running away. Its design is also bad in comparison with all the other bosses; he looks too cartoony and the stakes are never high. You don't care about any of the characters and the only reason you "care" about Lara is because of how well-established she already is as a videogame character/icon. If she was a new character, we would know nothing about her. You can play as Lara (Singleplayer/Multiplayer) or Totec (Multiplayer only) and the levels design changes accordingly.The game can be played with a single player and a second player can connect at any time - Locally or Online.Single player is good but I would suggest playing Local Co-op for a full, rich experience.Local Co-op is amazing - solving puzzles with a buddy is awesome. You can also kill your teammate so there are a ton of possibilities for revenge and a few laughs, usually followed by an impalled/crushed ally.On the other hand, Online Co-op is full of bugs and there are a lot of synch problems. Bullets doing nothing to enemies and Totec's spears not spawning (they are necessary to cross certain obstacles) are only some of the bugs I encountered with friends.The gameplay is this game's main strength; it focuses on platforming, combat and puzzle solving.Platforming is relatively simple. Lara and Totec can use their gadgets to get to higher places or to cross pits and chasms. Totec has a shield that allows Lara to jump on him and perform a bigger jump, allowing her to reach higher platforms; Lara can then pull him up using her grapple. Totec also has spears; once thrown against a wall, Lara can use these to cross certain obstacles.Combat is good. You have a lot of weapons to choose from but you'll find yourself using the same combination over and over again. Once you kill enough enemies, you'll enter some sort of berserk mode and you'll get an upgrade - mana/health regenaration, scatter shots or even better mines - that will last until you are hit by your enemies. This kind of makes the game's combat super easy. If you pick a powerful weapon and you keep regenarating mana, you'll be able to kill everything with ease. Your enemies are a bunch of clumsy demons and summons who are kind of shallow in design, but they offer a decent enough challenge later on, when their numbers are massive. Some of these creatures get a different color pallet on certain levels, which provides them with different abilites (ressurection, explosion when killed, etc.). My real gripe with the enemies is that you only come across a really limited number of different creatures. More variety would have been better.The puzzles are quite easy to figure out and only slightly harder to solve. You'll have to time jumps and dodges, activate pressure pads and deactivate hazards/barriers that block your way. Their design is really good and the scale grows bigger and more impressive in later levels. Unfortunately, even harder puzzles are sort of basic and provide no real challenge..To mix things up and add replay value, each level provides some optional challenges to complete. They can be really easy to complete - destroy all trucks in a level or jump 12 times over a trap - or "infuriating" (complete the whole level in under X minutes or  navigate a trap-filled hall on your first attempt). Once completed, these challenges provide helpful new weapons, health/mana upgrades or even relics. Relics are equippable items - they change your stats and help you in combat (better bombs, better speed, etc.).Sound is kinda generic - guns don't really sound all that great but it's serviceable (explosions sound good, though). The dialogue is really cheesy and considering the story is also bad, you won't care about what the characters are saying - not that it matters. The game features a good soundtrack - I might be wrong but I think some of it was used in Tomb Raider Anniversary and maybe even in TR Legend and Underworld.The game looks fairly decent. You'll have some graphical glitches from time to time but the game knows what it is and it tends to amaze you with huge environments  instead of with graphical detail. Character models are ok, but their lips do not move during cutscenes; the camera angle keeps changing so players won't notice.Overrall, this game is a great purchase if you enjoy inventive puzzle solving, mixed with a fair amount of combat and platforming. It might have big flaws, including what was supposed to be its main selling point (online co-op) but the gameplay is so satisfying and local co-op is so good that this is an experience I gladly recommend. The game currently costs 10€ - I'd suggest getting it on a sale. I think it is worth 5€ if you are desperate for a puzzle game but it goes on sale fairly often so I'd wait for a 75/80% discount.Final Score: 7.5 out of 10.

												Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light is exemplary coop ingenuity.Transplanting the Tomb Raider franchise onto an isometric shooter, its genius lies not within its clever puzzles or satisfying combat, but the lengths at which it has been designed from the ground up as a brilliant coop experience. It forces you to think with two players in mind instead of opting for the far simpler solution of just dropping another player in beside you, and this devotion makes for refreshingly unique puzzle designs and the means with which you navigate the world.The focus on teamwork is in large part based on the different character abilities between archaeologist, Lara Croft, and the ancient Mayan warrior, Totec. Each has various gear and moves (from a grappling hook, to a shield that can be raised and jumped on) and it's in using them in tandem that you can manage to make your way through environments that one person couldn't. It inspires cooperation in ways that simply providing double the fire power doesn't, putting you in situations where each player has a specific role and no one feels the lesser for theirs.It's a fairly radical departure for the series traditional gameplay hooks, but Guardian of Light still feels distinctly Tomb Raider. Though the perspective has changed and there's less of an emphasis on platforming, there are still plenty of supernatural monsters to kill and tombs to raid, with puzzles that are probably the best the series has ever seen. They revisit many of the same designs but in a way that's constantly layering on new challenges, requiring you continue expanding your perception of them even when on the surface they're born of the same basic template.I don't doubt that it's entirely possible to play Guardian of Light as a solo adventure and have a good amount of fun with it, but to me that would be missing a huge portion of what makes it so enjoyable. There's just nothing quite like the sort of beautiful coop design presented with a game like this, with playing with friends already being generally more entertaining and something so tailor made to that playstyle elevating it to new heights. There's something really special to me about games that can serve as essentially bonding moments between friends and family, and ones as smart and polished as this are all too rare.

Posted: February 2, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light Review 

			Views: 251		

			We take a look at the isometric view spinoff of the hit franchise Tomb Raider http://noobsthatplaygames.com/		

It’s a shame they didn’t take notes from Guardian of Light when developing the most recent reboot of Tomb Raider. While Lara croft in the most recent core entry in the Tomb Raider series is trying her best to shed all the enjoyable puzzles and adventuring that made the series famous to instead become the new quick time event action movie star and dethrone Drake from Uncharted, Lara Croft in the Guardians of Light offers everything that made Tomb Raider great.The game is centered on fast paced action combat, exploration, and completing various interesting and sometimes challenging puzzles.  Unlike the core entries in the franchise, Guardians of Light takes the approach of having players control the game from an isometric view point, this type of view point allows for a very enjoyable seamless co-op mode experience.As far as visuals go there’s nothing in this game that will overwhelm you, but for an isometric view game from 2010 it holds up very well. The level design on the other hand is absolutely brilliant, offering a wide variety of puzzles ranging from one room dungeons to entire expansive multi-tomb map sized puzzles. The puzzles are normally completed through various interactions between Lara and her co-op companion Totec, the Guardian of Light. Each character plays slightly different from one another, each with their own pros and cons, Totec is bulkier and has a shield so he fits more into the role of a tank, he also uses throwing spears as his primary weapon that can also be used to make platforms for the much lighter and more nimble and agile Lara Croft. Totec can also raise his shield above his head to use as a platform and then Lara can use her grappling hook to pull up Totec or make rope bridges for him to climb up. There are many instances in the game where you are put into a situation where you have to act very quickly and rely heavily on your partner to either lift you into the right position or to carry you to safety before you are either crushed, mauled, or mutilated, and in these intense, fast paced, high pressure situations is where the game shines.The combat handles just the way you’d expect it to for an isometric view arcade shooter. There aren’t really any complaints as long as you aren’t the guy who gets stuck as player 2 using a gamepad controller, because you’ll be SoL and instead of a crosshair you will get stuck with the tiniest little light that shines on the wall in the direction you are facing as your point of reference for the general area in which you’ll be firing. This honestly wouldn’t be that bad, when you see the light it works really well, but the problem is that it’s constantly being hidden behind objects in the foreground and you have to blindly fire at enemies while you franticly search for your little light. The game does offer a fairly extensive variety of weapons to choose from, from pistols to assault rifles to flame throwers, they’re all present and accounted for.  Each character has their own primary weapon; Lara’s being her pistols and Teco’s being his throwing spears, both of which have unlimited ammunition, all of the other weapons are useable by both characters and their ammunition is monitored by a depleting ammo bar below your health bar that is replenished by the abundant ammo drops located on the map and from enemy drops. The game tries to shake things up and keep the gameplay from feeling stale by adding various challenges for each level such as reach the end of the level by “X” amount of time, or blow up a certain number of random objects placed throughout the map. Completion of these challenges result in acquiring a unique perk or item that can be applied to your character to greatly aid you in your adventures.  An example of the most beneficial perk I came across during my adventures was a perk that became activated if I managed to chain together a large enough kill streak without being injured by any enemies, my gun would then switch over to rapid triple shot mode and allow me to plow through hordes of enemies like a true bonafide bad♥♥♥♥♥ The best part is that all the perks and items you acquire are useable on both characters, so you don’t have to worry about your partner hording the juicy loot.Overall Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light provides an excellent experience that becomes even that much more enjoyable when played with a friend in co-op. The fast paced action combat is thrilling and there is an abundance of quality puzzles that keeps you engaged and entertained. With the only complaint being minor control issues for player 2, the Guardian of Light is truly a game worth buying and enjoying alongside a friend.http://noobsthatplaygames.com/

												Nothing was better for my relationship than Guardian of Light, because it taught me to never trust my girlfriend when I cross a pit of spikes.The experience of playing GoL can easily be compared to Trine, and approaches the same level of co-op/ killing each other excellence. GoL is a mixture of puzzles, combat, arcade elements, and platforming all done from an isometric perspective. Most of the puzzles are clever and juggle between challenging players’ finesse and problem solving skills. There are deadly traps to avoid, and a fun physics system helps transform something as mundane as a boulder into basketball, transportation, or even makeshift artillery. A lot of these shenanigans will lead to player death, but that is also part of the fun.The combat is a mix of shooting and planting bombs that are detonated remotely. The controls feel tight, and dodge rolling keeps combat fair and exciting. Combat is also the area where the arcade elements are strongest: each level has a set of various challenges that are completed to boost score and unlock new items directly. The unlocks ranges from new weapons to stat boosts and offers players a healthy amount of options when comes to fighting foes. The arcade style of challenges also pushes players to die less, complete levels faster, and complete some neat tasks. None of the challenges ever get in the way of enjoying the game, and are generally a mix of things that can be done easily on the way to completing the campaign, and more difficult tasks that require practice.The absolute most important aspect of the game is the cooperative experience. Having someone to race with leaping across platforms, blow up with bombs, drop into a pit of spikes, leave behind, lock into cages, lead into traps, and just betray in general is a large part of what makes this game fun. Lara and her partner Totec are designed to rely on each other: he has a spear that he’s too fat to climb on but can help Lara reach new areas or a shield to lift and shield Lara, and she a grappling that can support the elephant that is Totec. Co-op also allows players to revive each other, which comes in handy when killing each other. Throughout the game it is simply a lot of fun to work together to find secrets, complete challenges, win, and mess around in general. With every person I play this game with, we end up making our own little challenges and games: balancing on a boulder as we mow down enemies, tag, horse with explosives and boulders, testing how far we can fall into spikes before being saved, etc. and it is an excellent diversion.Lara Croft and The Guardian of Light hits all the marks of a great spinoff and a great co-op experience. I had more fun with this than any other Tomb Raider game, so much so that I bought it multiple times on different platforms. The levels are well designed, the mechanics all feel balanced, and the game is well paced. Sure there is a story that can easily be ignored, but that pushes the game towards an arcade experience focused on having fun with your friends. Out of all the local co-op games I have played, including the old console days, GoL easily ranks high up on the list. That being said, solo is pretty fun on its own, but never quite reaches the same level of satisfaction.

												LC: GoL is a much more arcade-like game than many of the others in the Tomb Raider franchise, but it is no less fun to play.The story follows Lara and Totec as they attempt to prevent Xolotl from destroying the world. The story is told through various means within the game, from narration at the start to comic and "live" cutscenes. This could have possibly been made more consistent throughout, but in no way affects the quality of the story. It does at times seem like many of the classic villain tropes come through in Xolotl however: Manic laughter, taunting the player etc., but this isn't too over the top.The gameplay has 2 main styles: linear and open levels. The linear levels (usually in tombs) generally require fighting your way through monsters, solving puzzles with balls and hazards like spike pits and fire, and jumping puzzles. The open levels are similar in what they require from the player, but instead of funneling you through a tomb you are generally given a "hub", with multiple paths to tombs to "complete". You need to do all of them anyway, so it's sort of the illusion of an open level more than anything.The puzzles themselves are generally quite easy, although there are one or two of the jumping puzzles which, like in all games, can be a bit frustrating. Overall, though, for an arcade-level game they are well made. The fighting scenes, which can occur randomly at any time (monsters spawn from out of the ground), seem to result in a sort of pseudo-bullet-hell type gameplay, which isn't a bad thing. The game difficulty can be changed depending on how you like your fight scenes (easy being you just tear through enemies, and hard gives you enemies that soak up bullets).To aid the fight mechanic you can collect different weapons (machine guns to explosive grenades), powerups (health boosts etc.) and various relics. The relics require a charge which when filled can enhance your fighting power. At the endgame, when the top tier ones are unlocked it becomes very easy to fight through vast numbers of enemies, which the game will happily provide.The sound design is very good in this game, with dramatic music when required and more ambient music for within non-combat puzzle areas. Similarly, the voice acting is very good, even if it is only heard in cutscenes. Given the isometric-style view of the game, you never really see things in a close detail, but even at a distance the graphics in this game are very nice, from the rocky textures of walls and brickwork to the design of the monsters and characters you fight.The game plays either using a controller or a keyboard. Personally, I would just stick to using a controller, if you have one, as the arcade-like nature of the game suits this playstyle best.In terms of bugs: If you intend to use a controller, note that the game might not automatically assign it to player 1, so you may need to go into the options to manually assign it. I only had the game crash catastrophically once. No idea why it happened, but restarting it solved the issue.To summarise: If you want a more laid-back adventure game, then this is definitely worth buying. It isn't terribly difficult, but it does offer a nice story and nice gameplay.

												Lara Croft and the Gaurdian of Light is an isometric platforming-puzzle game developed by crystal dynamics. PlotLara is on the search for the Mirror of Smoke thought loss long ago in Central America. The mirror was originally formed by the keeper of darkness, Xolotl, to unleash monsters into the world. His nemesis Totec, the gaurdian of light, used the mirror against Xolotl and sealed him within the object. Many years later, Lara finds the mirror hidden within a temple. Unfortunately, she is ambushed by mercenaries who carelessly take the mirror and releases Xolotl and Totec from their slumber. With Xolotl free to unleash his monsters on the worldagain, Lara must work with Totec to stop Xolotl.GameplayThe game is a mixture of puzzle solving, platforming and combat. Each level sets you in a stage where you have to solve puzzles and platform around in order to progress. Along the way there are a wide range of enemies such as spiders, monsters, giants and skeletons, some of which have unique strengths and weaknesses. You also find plenty of traps such as explosives, spike traps, flame traps and pitafalls which will hinder your progress.  There are also unique challenges in each stage which when completed will offer either upgrades, artefacts or weapons. You have a health and ammo bar. Should your health depelte, you will restart at the latest checkpoint and lose score. There are plenty of weapons to find such as pistols, assault rifles, smg, minigun, sniper and spears each with different stats. There are also artifacts which give you a bonus of different stats.ControlsThe controls work well with a mouse and keyboard, however ther were instances where it was difficult to compplete challeneges and platforming due to key arrangement. I would highly recommend you use a controller.GraphicsThe visuals in the game are decent. The environment looks good with plenty of objects and flauna around which a well detaled. The character models, unfortunately don't look good with lack of texture detail.SoundAudio is a mix between good and not so good. The sound effects for weapons, traps and such are great. background music is good as well. While Lara's voice acting is good, Totec and Xotl aren't that great.ExtrasAs you play the game, you get score based on how well you performed in each level. When you reach a certain scroe threshhold, you unlock new costumes for Lara to use. There is also a free Kane and Lynch character DLC included witht he base game. Similar to the Kane and Azarael DLC, this basically changes the character models and some dialogue during campaign.Overall if you are looking for a good tomb raider game to play with a friend or by yourself, this is the game for you.

												The Guardian of Light is among the many spin-off games to the Tomb Raider franchise. Due to the difference in gameplay and continuity from the console games it is classified as a "spin-off". When labeling it as "spin-off", meaning this game is not a sequel to the "Avalon/Atlantis" trilogy that precedes it. While Keely Hawes repraises her role as Lara Croft, there is no mentionings of Amanda, Natla, or the Excaliber for this game. It is therefore a standalone "no need to play the other games" type of game. With that lecture put aside I will discuss the plot. Lara travels to an unspecific country in Central America to obtain an artifact called the "Mirror of Smoke". After making through a dangerous and perilous journey through the jungle, Lara finds the mirror of interest. Unknown to her, a band of merceneries lead by an arrogant warlord were tailing her. Upon the mishandling of the mirror, it sharders and unleashes the merciless Xolotl the god of lightning and death. At the same time the statue of Totec comes to life, who immediately gives Lara aid in her new mission to stop the newly resurrected Xolotl before the light of dawn or witness the rise of Xolotl's army that will plunder the planet. The Guardian of Light offers an over head camera view gameplay that differs from the traditional Tomb Raider games. While in the other games the camera is controllable, in this game the camera is always in over head view. Despite this small change, the game is fun with the abundences of puzzles and power ups. It offers a straight up action game that isn't as deeply written as the traditional Tomb Raider games. But it offers something different and just telling you "Hey, we're making a fun puzzle adventure spin-off, nothing more". It's worth checking out, if you like to take a detour from the bigger and more noteworthy Tomb Raider games you are use to playing.

Glitches are easily fixed by reloading a checkpoint or replaying the level.Replayability is limited. You can only replay the stages a few times to earn all the collectibles or challenges. After all that, there is no point to replay anymore.100% Achievement is moderately easy.The DLCs adds a little content into the game, but some challenges can be quite frustrating to complete if you aren't very good in the game.My Score: 8/10

												TL DR: do you want to have fun with friends/brother/sister/boy/girlfriend etc? This is the game for you. Even if you aren't familiar with the TR series you will have quite some fun with it. (Two controllers recommended)Are you looking for the typical Tomb Raider game with the pretty graphics, intense storyline amazing quality effects and that sexy Lara's A$$?This is not the game for you.This is not the typical Tomb Raider game and is not even the typical gameplay you could find into a TR game.Yeah indeed, there are several artifacts to find (some are even really well hidden), yes there are different puzzles, yes there are even some difficult challenges.But the gameplay itself is not the usual.First of all the view is not a third person one but an isometric one (if you like RPGs or Diablo you will love this).Second there is a lot of action; yes there will be a lot of enemies to kill and you will find yourself surrounded more than one time.Third you can play this co-op and some puzzles will even change during multiplayer to "force you" to cooperate to go on.I really recommend the use of a controller even because it's a simple and plain game with simple commands (keyboard + mouse in this particular case is not that comfy like on Diablo 3 for example).The gameplay itself is pretty much linear even if, in some levels, you will need to go back and forth through the map to go on.If you take your time to do everything you will find several relics and weapons (and you will be amazed...there are quite plenty of them). The relics will give you different advantages (or disadvantages) on speed, ammo, health and so on. (Like the objects on a RPG game but in a very and more simple way). If you get the most rare ones (both relics and weapons...yes there are some quite unusual weapons) you will technically become immortal.Longevity is really not a strong point of this game. By skipping the challenges, the secondary puzzles and the tombs to explore you can easily finish this game in 5 hours or even less if you are a skilled player or you play at the easiest difficulty.Even if the different scenarios and the effects are really good looking don't expect a quality AAAA graphic. In fact there are really few cut scenes with the game graphic. Most of them are pretty draws with Lara narrative voice.I recommend this game if you want a simple game to chill a bit alone or with a friend or a relative or a parent or the love of your life. It's fun and you will have fun.I don't recommend this game if you are a TR purist. You will definitely not like this game. Or if you are looking for a long and complicate game. 												Games are not always "fun" for me - they're often work that I like to do. This game is fun. It's work too, but it's also actually really fun. This game is like a perfect mix of Diablo and Mario Brothers.  If you like isometric platform games, you'll love this game. If you get annoyed by fast-paced action puzzles, you will hate this game. Let's get my cons out of the way first:-Controlling this game with a keyboard and mouse is REALLY confusing and difficult! You have to reorient yourself to move Lara in the direction you actually want, and this is the cause of lots and lots of deaths (points lost.) -There are some bugs, some of which are to your advantage, but most of which ruin your efforts. None of the bugs are so bad that it's unplayable at any point. - Some of the levels are repetitive, meaning you have to do the same type of puzzle, just in a new setting. - Some of the timed puzzles are made very annoying because controlling Lara is not easy. She can jump too far (when she jumps just right every other time,) go in the wrong direction, react too slowly, or get hidden behind an object. Now on my to pros:- Turning the combat down to "easy" does not reduce the difficulty of the puzzles. This means that if you prefer playing the game for the puzzles and the fun experience without the annoyance of difficult monsters, you can play it that way. It's still a lot of fun if you're not interested in difficult combat. - The levels, though repetitive at times, are designed well. They are fun, interesting, and pose just enough challenges. Some of the challenges will make you frusturated, some will take a long time to figure out, while others are a little too easy. If a puzzle is too hard for you, there are tons of Youtube videos available to show you what to do. There was only one instance where I had to get help because I tried about a 100 different things and kept failing. Once I watched the video I felt like an idiot, because the solution was so easy - just not obvious. - You can repeat levels over and over. If you're a completionist, this game gives you as many chances as you want without having to repeat too much. - If you're not a completionist and just play for the experience, not all the accomplishments, that's okay too. You can still fully enjoy the game without worrying about every detail. The so-so parts:-The story. It's nothing special. There's nothing meaty here. -The music is rarely fitting. It's either too repetitive, or too dramatic for the scene. It isn't bad music, just too much at times. The longer it takes you to make it through a level, the longer you have to listen to the simple repetitiveness of it. Conclusion:I can't see anyone disliking this game if they're a fan of the genre. It's not the best isometric platform game out there, but it's still great and really enjoyable. If you don't like the genre, this title will not convert you. If you're a fan of Tomb Raider in general, you'll enjoy this, even if you're not typically a fan of isometric games. I personally don't care about getting every achievement in this game. I even completed one level with zero points in the end because I died so many times. I know it makes me look bad, but with this game I don't care that much. I don't need to score well with each level in order to keep progressing, and I'm enjoying just passing every level without worrying about the details. I'm thankful for a game that lets me do that!

												This game is good. Very good, even. Resisting the urge to gush, I can honestly say that I had fun all the way throughout this game, and that is VERY rare for me these days. It was a rather bold step of Crystal Dynamics to make a Tomb Raider game in this vein, rather than how all other Tomb Raiders have been, but I'm really glad they did. It's still very much a Tomb Raider game, in that there are platforming puzzles, lots of enemies to kill, and plenty of treasure to find. This bird's-eye perspective, however, allows the action to be a lot faster paced. Enemies can (and will) swarm from all around you, while floor tiles ignite on fire, and arrow traps shoot out from the walls. It can get very hectic, but it never gets overwhelming.One area in particular where this game succeeds, and many others get wrong, is in the area of specialized skills. Many games will have so many that it gets overwhelming, or just one major one, giving the puzzles an arbitrary feel.I never felt that way with this game, though. Playing single player, you get all of Lara's skills, plus all of Totec's (he's the Guardian of Light). Figuring out which ones to use in which situation felt very organic. In fact, it felt like the solution I used to solve several puzzles was not the one the developers intended, and I LOVE when you're allowed to do that. Too many games put too much importance on HOW you achieve the goal, rather than on the fact that you DID achieve it.This is designed for co-op, no doubt about it, but it is an extremely solid single player experience. Never did I feel "oh man, I could really use a second player here," which is a testament to fantastic game design.The graphics are quite good, the music and sound effects fit, and the voice acting is top notch.It's a fairly quick game (I beat it in around 6 hours), but it's one I would have no problem going back to to collect more trophies. If a friend bought it and wanted to play co-op, I would absolutely say "yes."

Posted: April 1, 2015
												"Prince of Persia" - that is exactly what came to my mind when I completed the 1st hour on the game. But later on I found out that the game is way more than just another rip off from the classic trilogy of PoP. So, let me get to the points straight away (but mind it, this is my firs title feature Lara Croft) -  Graphics:The games has an immensely good graphics - the visuals looks stunning specially if you play it on a big screen. The Level designing is very nice and complex(which suites the context). The artworks are awesome and the lighting and shadow effects will steal your mind. Surprisingly the game is somewhat "light" on my PC and I could switch context using ALT+TAB with no fuss. Grameplay:When you play an adventure game with 3rd person perspective and angled top view camera - the gameplay and the controls, specially, becomes a very critical indeed. I am playing the game with the XboX 360 PC controller and the inputs work just fine. In spite of trying 32 times for that "Better mouse Trap" achievement, I can tell you that controller is the better way to play this game than keyboard and mouse. since it is an Adventure RPG kind of game I think that developers should have invested more in the item and relic slots.Yes the game works just fine with 2 items and 1 relic slot but I feel it would have been better(read more in numbers). Overall the gameplay and controls are very much in sync with the levels and camera controls. Audio:The in game sound is worthy enough to get a separate mention in my review. It feels awesome when you listen to the music or to the in game environmental sounds. The sounds change dramatically when the game scenario changes (including the death of your character). With my Steelseries Siverai V2 the sound feels awesome! Story:This is one of the weakest links in the game - the Story!. I am not saying it is not there but it is somewhat generic in nature. I mean - it is nothing outstanding just a standard layout of story. Stupid people makes a mistake and unleashed terror on earth - now its up to you to stop it once and for all. yeah yeah we get it!!.... Well, that was the same layout I have found on Diablo (all versions) and in PoP games but the different twist and turns are what kept the players kept us mentioning about them every other review. This is what I feel what is lacking. Misc:There are things that I need to mention here -  The cut scenes are not that good - it could have been much better than they are. The Challenge Tombs are just rips offs from the PoPs life upgrade passages. The overall complexity of the game is very very satisfying and so as the rewards. Combine them with steam achievements and you will feel much complete with your gaming experience. Grate re playability All in all the game is a must have for me that comes with a solid bang for the buck. I have not yet played the Co-Op so I cannot comment on it- hopefully it will be as better as the single player one.- * happy raiding * -

												Even though you might think Lara Croft = Tomb Raider = not very good like I initially did, this game is surprisingly really good. It's not without its problems: sometimes the fixed isometric viewpoint can make jumps a little tricky and you'll find yourself flying into a pit rather than landing on a platform, but such instances are rare and it's overall far better than the awful third person cameras from Tomb Raider games.  Sometimes the weapon aiming is a little bit of a pain as well. There seems to be a bit of auto-aim: you point the right stick in the general direction you want to use a weapon and the game auto-targets enemies for you. Sometimes though, you'll have a little guy you can kill in one shot next to a giant guy, and the little guy is rushing you.  You'll desperately want to kill the little guy before he hits you, but the auto-aiming keeps hitting the big guy and you end up taking damage. Once again though, such instances are few and far between. Really fun overall though!

Posted: February 25, 2015
												This little game is not as much fun as people here on Steam make it seem. It's actually the opposite.Let's see what's good and what's bad.The story is almost non-existent. Sure, there is some generic uninteresting intro, but that's it. To be honest, I don't mind it as I didn't expect much story from a game of this style (like Alien Swarm which also had very little story)The graphics is okay. There's nothing that exceptional to mention here. Maybe just that even though the graphics is not that special, it doesn't run as well as I'd expect (on my main computer it's fine, on my laptop it is not).The sound is average and there's also some music. The soundtrack isn't too memorable but I'm glad it's there. Games tend to get quite "sterile" without music.What really kills this game is the gameplay. That's a major flaw. Controls are awkward and your character sometimes does whatever he/she likes. It might be better on consoles, but I'm using a PC, so I'm rating that. There are many frustrating and unfair puzzles. Don't get me wrong - the idea behind most puzzles is good, but the execution is weak. Why? Controls. Movement is fine, but jumping is a disaster. You often end up falling to your death and as a consequence lose your valuable points. Which raises the question: Why the hell are you punished for developer's fault? That's ridiculous. There are several moves and tools you can use to get through the levels and puzzles. You've got two tools - a spear and a rope. Both are pretty useful to get to high or distant places. But good luck getting back down. You're forced to use a leap of faith as there is no way to drop while hanging on the edge of platforms. There might aswell be, but it's not in the tips and I haven't found it by myself. Such a thing should be mandatory in Lara Croft games.There's also a coop mode which I haven't tried yet. If it plays better than singleplayer, this review might change to positive in the future. It's a fat chance though.To sum it all up, the developers had ideas but clearly didn't know what they were doing. It's a shame because this doesn't look like a bad title. Well, let's hope they learn and don't ♥♥♥♥ up like this with their next game.

Posted: July 18, 2015
												Pros- Great graphics and artwork. Still holds up well for a 5 year old game- Excellent level design. Good layouts, good puzzles, teaches the player to play the game by making things obvious enough to figure out without needing too many tutorials- A great reward system for completing certain tasks on each level- A decent amount of useful collectables, weapons and upgrades that make the game really fun and challenging- I really like the integration of the Relic powerup system. It's something to strive for and gives lots of points when active, which gives the game an old school feel. Also the rewards from getting the level high scores are really useful and fun to use.- Nice music- Lara's movement ability (not the controls)- Good ambience- Good Punchy Sound FX that really let you feel what's happening in the game- Lara Croft...Cons- Voice acting is hit and miss. For example, Lara's big strapping aztec buddy sounds like Tigger from Winnie the Pooh. Not really what I would call a convincing warrior voice- Long load after dying, rather than instant respawn like in most other games. This breaks gameflow- The controls are finicky. You can either use keyboard and mouse, in which case aiming is great but movement is really hard or you can use a controller, in which case aiming is really hard because there is no crosshair guide like the mouse and using a stick to aim and shoot is always harder and less precise than a mouse. I think they could have done a lot better here. For players using a keyboard and a mouse, it would have been better if the camera rotated with Lara, rather than keeping the same top down iso angle (for single player). For players using a controller, it would have been really useful to have a little bit of assistance with auto aim for both movement and aiming. If the player is pushing the right stick in the general direction of an enemy, while shooting, the projectiles should be heading towards the enemy. It's so easy to be slightly off with a small stick like there is on any controller and the game really punishes for it. The same thing happens with movement, especially when jumping between platforms or near edges. I've lost count of the number of times where Lara jumps into the abyss because I'm slightly off with the stick. It might not be purist, but breaking gameflow is worse and can get very frustrating (especially because of the long load times after a death)- Weapon selection with the d-pad is too sensitive. Once again, a bit of intelligence from the game to figure out that I've kind of pressed right means I should get that weapon selected. This would be very useful, considering I'm trying to manage 2 other sticks with my thumbs at the same time. 												Very enjoyable isometric strategy / shooter / puzzler. Definitely recommended if you're a fan of Tomb Raider even though it deviates from the 3d norm. I'm not particularly a fan of tomb raider and I enjoyed it.The story is that a curse/god is released and you play as Lara adventuring your way through many levels then do a boss battle to put the boss back into his prison.The game consists of shooting, dodging and solving puzzles in roughly equal measure. If you rush the game without the extras you'll have it done in 3 - 5 hours. These are 3 - 5 very enjoyable hours and well worth the price.The levels offer a challenge but aren't too hard and you can generally figure out what you have to do quickly. This is no hardcore puzzler, it's a casual puzzler. In the levels there are lots of optional puzzles which reward you with various things. There are also optional tombs containing puzzles that reward you with very nice extra things.There are a few things to help you along, and this is where the strategy comes in.You can hold 3 weapons plus unlimited low-damage bombs and your spear (which despite being the weakest damage weapon will be required quite often for puzzle solving).You can hold 2 artifacts and 1 relic, which change the attributes of things like defense, speed and attack in varying ways.The relic is only activated after you've killed enough enemies without being hurt, or after picking up enough diamonds and when you take another hit, the relic effects are gone.The ammo is very simple. It's an ammo pool for all weapons (except spear which takes no ammo) and the more powerful weapons use more ammo per shot, simple as that.This is all introduced gradually, and does sound confusing, but it's easy to master once you've been playing a little while and the artifacts and relics allow you a few options that can turn a battle where you haven't got a hope around.Checkpoints are frequent which is great. And you can quit the game and it'll resume from your last checkpoint next time.The graphics get a bit repetative - lots of beige and brown rooms with stairs and pathways. But the action flows nicely and you're so busy either battling or figuring out where to go next that you don't really care.Lastly the boss fight was thoroughly enjoyable. It wasn't particularly challenging on normal difficulty, but it lasted a few minutes and didn't get stale or boring.There are four gripes I have.1. There are times when the aim-assist (you'll need it, really) can let you down, this is especially frustrating with the weapons that take lots of ammo per shot, but mostly it was very good.2. Jumping gaps can also be slightly irritating if you misjudge the direction of the controller.3. The mission briefing pauses the game to pop up on screen. This can break a nice flow you have and left me saying "I know, I read it before, just let me play damnit". However, these are necessary so you know what you're doing.4. It's too easy on normal difficulty.One last thing. In one screenshot you see spiders. There are many spiders in this game. Nothing really pounces and there are no jumpscares.

												Very enjoyable isometric strategy / shooter / puzzler. Definitely recommended if you're a fan of Tomb Raider even though it deviates from the 3d norm. I'm not particularly a fan of tomb raider and I enjoyed it.The story is that a curse/god is released and you play as Lara adventuring your way through many levels then do a boss battle to put the boss back into his prison.The game consists of shooting, dodging and solving puzzles in roughly equal measure. If you rush the game without the extras you'll have it done in 3 - 5 hours. These are 3 - 5 very enjoyable hours and well worth the price.The levels offer a challenge but aren't too hard and you can generally figure out what you have to do quickly. This is no hardcore puzzler, it's a casual puzzler. In the levels there are lots of optional puzzles which reward you with various things. There are also optional tombs containing puzzles that reward you with very nice extra things.There are a few things to help you along, and this is where the strategy comes in.You can hold 3 weapons plus unlimited low-damage bombs and your spear (which despite being the weakest damage weapon will be required quite often for puzzle solving).You can hold 2 artifacts and 1 relic, which change the attributes of things like defense, speed and attack in varying ways.The relic is only activated after you've killed enough enemies without being hurt, or after picking up enough diamonds and when you take another hit, the relic effects are gone.The ammo is very simple. It's an ammo pool for all weapons (except spear which takes no ammo) and the more powerful weapons use more ammo per shot, simple as that.This is all introduced gradually, and does sound confusing, but it's easy to master once you've been playing a little while and the artifacts and relics allow you a few options that can turn a battle where you haven't got a hope around.Checkpoints are frequent which is great. And you can quit the game and it'll resume from your last checkpoint next time.The graphics get a bit repetative - lots of beige and brown rooms with stairs and pathways. But the action flows nicely and you're so busy either battling or figuring out where to go next that you don't really care.Lastly the boss fight was thoroughly enjoyable. It wasn't particularly challenging on normal difficulty, but it lasted a few minutes and didn't get stale or boring.There are four gripes I have.1. There are times when the aim-assist (you'll need it, really) can let you down, this is especially frustrating with the weapons that take lots of ammo per shot, but mostly it was very good.2. Jumping gaps can also be slightly irritating if you misjudge the direction of the controller.3. The mission briefing pauses the game to pop up on screen. This can break a nice flow you have and left me saying "I know, I read it before, just let me play damnit". However, these are necessary so you know what you're doing.4. It's too easy on normal difficulty.One last thing. In one screenshot you see spiders. There are many spiders in this game. Nothing really pounces and there are no jumpscares.
